citing_paper_authors: Kenneth Ward, Church | William A., Gale | Patrick, Hanks | Donald, Hindle
raw_text: We have found that if we first tag every word in the corpus with a part of speech using a method such as Church (1988) or DeRose (1988), and then measure associations between tagged words, we can identify interesting contrasts between verbs associated with a following preposition to~in and verbs associated with a following infinitive marker to~to
clean_text: We have found that if we first tag every word in the corpus with a part of speech using a method such as Church (1988) or DeRose (1988), and then measure associations between tagged words, we can identify interesting contrasts between verbs associated with a following preposition to~in and verbs associated with a following infinitive marker to~to.

citing_paper_authors: Enis, Sert | Mehmet Ali, Yatbaz | Deniz, Yuret
raw_text: This work is to be distinguished from supervised part-of-speech disambiguation systems, which use labeled training data (Church, 1988), unsupervised disambiguation systems, which use a dictionary of possible tags for each word (Merialdo, 1994), or prototype driven systems which use a small set of prototypes for each class (Haghighi and Klein, 2006)
clean_text: This work is to be distinguished from supervised part-of-speech disambiguation systems, which use labeled training data (Church, 1988), unsupervised disambiguation systems, which use a dictionary of possible tags for each word (Merialdo, 1994), or prototype driven systems which use a small set of prototypes for each class (Haghighi and Klein, 2006).

citing_paper_authors: William A., Gale | Kenneth Ward, Church | David, Yarowsky
raw_text: Much of this work offers the prospect that a disambiguation system might be able to input unrestricted text and tag each word with the most likely sense with fairly reasonable accuracy and efficiency, just as part of speech taggers (e.g., Church (1988)) can now input unrestricted text and assign each word with the most likely part of speech with fairly reasonable accuracy and efficiency
clean_text: Much of this work offers the prospect that a disambiguation system might be able to input unrestricted text and tag each word with the most likely sense with fairly reasonable accuracy and efficiency, just as part of speech taggers (e.g., Church (1988)) can now input unrestricted text and assign each word with the most likely part of speech with fairly reasonable accuracy and efficiency.
